{{EngvarB|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} The '''tutorial system''' is a method of university teaching where the main focus is on regular, very small group teaching sessions. It was established by and is still practised by the [[University of Oxford]] and the [[University of Cambridge]] in the United Kingdom. In addition to attending [[lectures]] and other classes, students are taught by faculty fellows in groups of one to three on a weekly basis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Personalised learning|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/admissions/undergraduate/student-life/exceptional-education/personalised-learning|website=University of Oxford|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bonetti|first1=Lisa|title=How will I be taught?|url=https://www.undergraduate.study.cam.ac.uk/courses/how-will-i-be-taught|website=undergraduate.study.cam.ac.uk|publisher=University of Cambridge|accessdate=25 March 2018|date=6 February 2018}}</ref> These sessions are called "tutorials" at Oxford and "supervisions" at Cambridge. One benefit of the tutorial system is that students receive direct feedback on their weekly essays or work in a small discussion setting. The [[University of Buckingham]] also practices the weekly tutorial system since it was set up as England's first private university in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tutorial and small group teaching|url=https://www.buckingham.ac.uk/about/ratio|website=University of Buckingham|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref>
Student tutorials are generally more academically challenging and rigorous than standard lecture and test format courses, because during each session students are expected to orally communicate, defend, analyse, and critique the ideas of others as well as their own in conversations with the [[Tutor (officer)|tutor]] and fellow-students. As a pedagogic model, the tutorial system has great value because it creates learning and assessment opportunities which are highly authentic and difficult to fake.<ref>Palfreyman, D. (2008). 'The Oxford Tutorial' (OxCHEPS) [http://oxcheps.new.ox.ac.uk/Publications/Resources/OxCHEPS_OP1_08.pdf].</ref>{{nonspecific|date=January 2015}}<!-- no papers are listed there on the given web page, as of 2015-01-07 -->
Outside the United Kingdom, a small number of universities have a tutorial system influenced by the Oxbridge system: [[Williams College]] in Massachusetts,<ref>{{cite web|title=Tutorials|url=https://www.williams.edu/academics/tutorials/|website=Williams College|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref> [[Honors Tutorial College]] of [[Ohio University]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Hallmarks of a Tutorial Education|url=https://www.ohio.edu/honors/future-students/programs/hallmarks.cfm|website=Honors Tutorial College|publisher=Ohio University|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref> [[Sarah Lawrence College]] in New York, and [[New College of Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tutorials|url=https://www.ncf.edu/admissions/why-new-college/unique-academic-program/tutorials/|website=New College of Florida|accessdate=25 March 2018}}</ref> These tutorials are often limited, either restricting them to those on an "[[honors program]]", or offering them as a single class rather than being the central feature of the university's teaching.

{{pp-pc1}} [[File:Washitaw Nation Super Sunday 2014.jpg|thumb|Washitaw Nation at the Mardi Gras Indians Super Sunday, [[New Orleans]] 2014]] The '''Washitaw Nation''', or ''Washitaw de Dugdahmoundyah'', is a group of [[Black Americans]] that claim to be a sovereign [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] nation within the boundaries of the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Truth+submerged+shall+rise+again%3a+Paul+Barton+writes+on+how+the+Mende...-a0124444696|title=Truth submerged shall rise again: Paul Barton writes on how the Mende people of West Africa influenced the Olmec Civilisation in the Americas.." The Free Library. 2004 IC Publications Ltd. 18 Nov. 2018|last=Barton|first=Paul|date=October 1, 2004|work=[[The Free Library]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Their name is taken from that of the [[Ouachita tribe]],<ref name="splcenter" /> who are also eponymous of the [[Washita River]] and of [[Washita, Oklahoma|Washita]], [[Oklahoma]]. The group is part of the [[sovereign citizen movement]], a movement whose members generally believe that they are not subject to any [[statute]]s or proceedings at the [[Federal government of the United States|federal]], [[State governments of the United States|state]], or municipal levels.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Erwin|first1=James L.|title=Declarations of Independence: Encyclopedia of American Autonomous and Secessionist Movements|date=2006|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0313332678|page=205|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pYrlk8fDC50C&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205&dq=Washitaw+%22sovereign+citizen%22&source=bl&ots=NJxXnBrtgM&sig=K2NfZe58Xh6Iw5vUphXCn4-pW_0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjE7sG6vP7KAhWGUhQKHRwsA4kQ6AEIODAE#v=onepage&q=Washitaw%20%22sovereign%20citizen%22&f=false|accessdate=February 17, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Nelson">{{cite web|last1=Nelson|first1=Leah|title=Memphis Stew|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2015/memphis-stew|website=Intelligence Report|publisher=SPLC|accessdate=February 17, 2016}}</ref>
The Washitaw Nation was headed by Verdiacee Hampton Goston (also known as Verdiacee Turner, also known as Empress Verdiacee Tiari Washitaw Turner Goston El-Bey, ca. 1927–2014<ref>{{cite news |title= Former Richwood mayor dies |publisher= KNOE.com |url= http://www.knoe.com/story/25397593/former-richwood-mayor-dies |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140512222500/http://www.knoe.com/story/25397593/former-richwood-mayor-dies |archivedate= 2014-05-12 |df= }}</ref>). She was mayor of [[Richwood, Louisiana]] in 1975 and 1976, and again from 1980 to 1984.<ref name="Empress">{{cite web |title=Empress Goston's legacy continues in 40th Anniversary |url=http://www.monroefreepress.net/2017/06/19/empress-gostons-legacy-continues-in-40th-anniversary/}} Monroe Free Press</ref> She is the author of the self-published book ''Return of the Ancient Ones'' (1993). Goston asserts that the United Nations "registers the Washitaw as indigenous people No. 215".<ref name="splcenter" />
==Classification== In 1999, the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] estimated that the group had about 200 hard-core members, noting its popularity among followers of [[Moorish Science Temple of America|Moorish Science]], a nationalist movement. The asserted legal basis for the establishment of the Washitaw Nation is a theory that individuals and groups may declare "sovereignty" and may separate themselves from state and federal governments, a concept earlier used by the [[Posse Comitatus (organization)|Posse Comitatus]]. The argument is also made that [[Napoleon]] only sold "the streets of [[New Orleans]] and a military barracks" and that the rest of Louisiana was stolen from the Washitaw.<ref name="splcenter">[http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?pid=593 "Born on the Bayou"], [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] ''Intelligence Report'', Spring 1999.</ref>
Various United States courts have held that the Washitaw Nation is fictional and that it is not recognized as a sovereign nation.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. v. HENLEY|url=http://www.leagle.com/decision/In%20FDCO%2020100412560/U.S.%20v.%20HENLEY|accessdate=17 February 2016|quote=The Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals characterized the Nation of Washitaw as fictional. Bybee v. City of Paducah, 46 Fed. Appx. 735, 736 (6th Cir. 2002), unpublished. Other federal courts decline to recognize the Washitaw Nation as a legitimate sovereign.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=United States Attorney's Office|url=http://www.justice.gov/archive/tax/usaopress/2003/txdv032003Sep17.html|accessdate=February 17, 2016|date=September 17, 2003}}</ref>
==Actions== The Washitaw Nation is the accrediting agent for a [[diploma mill]], the City University of Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite book| last= Bear| first= John| title=Bears' guide to earning degrees by distance learning|publisher=Ten Speed Press|isbn=978-1-58008-431-4| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=k67XC_7y5xEC&pg=PA196&dq=%22Association+of+Accredited+Private+Schools%22+Washitaw&hl=en&ei=Q_BeTI3qCYaw4QbZ4oyfDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Association%20of%20Accredited%20Private%20Schools%22%20Washitaw&f=false|author2=Mariah Bear |page=195|date=2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Burgin|first=Aaron|title=Lake Elsinore City Council candidate's doctorate from online school accredited by separatists|url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_S_sdegree20.2389424.html|newspaper=The Press Enterprise|date=September 19, 2008}}</ref>

{{Update|portions of its subject|date=September 2011}} {{Year Zero alternate reality game}} '''''Year Zero''''' is an [[alternate reality game]] (ARG) by American studio 42 Entertainment based on the [[Nine Inch Nails]] [[Year Zero (album)|concept album of the same name]], its expected follow-up, and a possible accompanying film or television project.{{cite web | url = http://www.kerrangradio.co.uk/Article.asp?id=362865&spid | title = Kerrang discusses movie possibility with Trent Reznor | work = [[Kerrang!]] | date = 2007-03-06 | accessdate = 2007-03-13 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070309122805/http://www.kerrangradio.co.uk/Article.asp?id=362865&spid |archivedate = 2007-03-09}} Although the album was released on April 16, 2007 in Europe, and the following day worldwide,{{cite web | url = http://www.nin.com/current/index.html | title = nine inch nails: current | date = 2007-02-05 | publisher = NIN.com | accessdate = 2007-02-13}} the game had been underway since roughly February 12, 2007 and was expected to continue for approximately eighteen months.{{cite web | title = RIAA Goes After NINE INCH NAILS Fans Over Deliberate Leak Campaign | publisher = [[Blabbermouth.net]] | date = 2007-04-03 | url = http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=69841 | accessdate = 2007-04-04}} The game was created by [[42 Entertainment]], the same group responsible for the ''[[Halo 2]]'' promotional alternative reality game ''[[I Love Bees]]''.{{cite web | last = Reuters | authorlink = Reuters | title = Cryptic Web sites build buzz for Nine Inch Nails | publisher = [[CNN]] | date = 2007-04-02 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/04/02/nineinchnails.reut/index.html | accessdate = 2007-04-06 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070408082309/http://www.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/04/02/nineinchnails.reut/index.html | archivedate = 2007-04-08}}{{cite web | url = http://www.digitmag.co.uk/news/index.cfm?NewsID=7247 | title = 42 creates viral campaign for Nine Inch Nails | publisher = digitmag.co.uk | date = 2007-02-14 | accessdate = 2007-02-16}} [[Trent Reznor]], frontman and sole member of the band, has called the game "a new entertainment form". In response to criticism{{cite web | url = http://www.stv.tv/content/out/music/spotlight/display.html?id=feeddb:4494 | title = Nine Inch Nails - Pretty PR Machine | author = Jay Shukla | publisher = [[STV (TV network)|STV]] | date = 2007-03-26 | accessdate = 2007-04-08 | quote = In appropriating the methods of the PR companies to promote his own art, Reznor is not only leaving himself open to attack, he is raising serious questions about control, manipulation and authenticity.}} regarding the promotion of the album, Reznor stated: {{cquote|The term "marketing" sure is a frustrating one for me at the moment. What you are now starting to experience IS "year zero". It's not some kind of gimmick to get you to buy a record - it IS the art form... and we're just getting started. Hope you enjoy the ride.{{cite web | url = http://www.nin-thespiral.com | title = The Spiral (registration required) | accessdate = 2006-02-05}} }} ==Premise== [[Image:AIR flier.jpg|thumb|upright|An [[Characters and organizations in the Year Zero alternate reality game#Art is Resistance|Art is Resistance]] flier from the ''Year Zero'' ARG.]] Reznor said that ''Year Zero'' is a [[concept album]],{{cite web | url = http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=64684 | title = NINE INCH NAILS Mainman On New CD: 'I Wrote The Soundtrack To A Movie That Doesn't Exist' | publisher = Blabbermouth | date = 2007-01-03 | accessdate = 2007-02-09}} "could be about the end of the world", and marked a "shift in direction" in that it "doesn't sound like ''[[With Teeth]]''." The 2006 tour merchandise designs featured overt references to the [[Military of the United States|United States military]], which "reflects future directions." In an interview with [[Gigwise.com]], Reznor stated that the concept behind ''Year Zero'' was partially inspired by his feelings toward the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]]. He further explained,
I really wanted to focus on something that was at the forefront of my consciousness which is, as an American, I'm appalled by the behavior of our government, the direction that it has taken and the direction that it's taken everyone else in the world and its arrogance... I decided to write an essay about where the world might be if we continue down the path that we're on with a neo-con-esque government doing whatever it pleases...{{cite web | last = Gregory | first = Jason | title = Trent Reznor Blasts The American Government | publisher = GIGWise.com | date = 2007-03-26 | url = http://www.gigwise.com/news.asp?contentid=29753 | accessdate = 2007-04-18}}
To this end, the storyline of ''Year Zero'' borrows heavily from such well-known [[dystopia]]n fiction as [[George Orwell|George Orwell's]] ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'' (government surveillance), [[Aldous Huxley]]'s ''[[Brave New World]]'' (use of drugs to subdue the populace), [[Ray Bradbury|Ray Bradbury's]] ''[[Fahrenheit 451]]'' (large-scale censorship and uniformism), and [[Yevgeny Zamyatin|Yevgeny Zamyatin's]] ''[[We (novel)|We]]'' (synthesis of church and state). Specific plot elements bear a resemblance to the [[Philip K. Dick]] short story ''[[Faith of Our Fathers (short story)|Faith of Our Fathers]]'', including hallucinogens in the water supply, an oppressive, heavily militaristic state, aggressive government monitoring of the populace, and a venerated entity which manifests in many forms. In keeping with the [[dystopian]] theme, Year Zero takes place in 2022, the same year as the 1973 film ''[[Soylent Green]]''. ==Plot== {{main|Campaign timeline of the Year Zero alternate reality game}} The story takes place in the United States in the year 2022, [[Year Zero (political notion)|which has been termed "Year 0" by the US government]], being the year that America was reborn. The U.S. had suffered several major terrorist attacks, including attacks on [[Los Angeles]] and [[Seattle]]. In response, the government granted itself emergency powers and seized absolute control on the country. The U.S. government is now a [[Christian fundamentalist]] [[theocracy]], maintaining control of the populace through institutions like the [[Characters and organizations in the Year Zero alternate reality game#Bureau of Morality|Bureau of Morality]] and the [[Characters and organizations in the Year Zero alternate reality game#First Evangelical Church of Plano|First Evangelical Church of Plano]], and locked into near constant war abroad against their aggressors, with the implied ulterior motive to expand their spheres of influence. Americans must get licenses to marry, bear children, etc. Subversive activities can result in these licenses being revoked. Dissenters regularly disappear from their homes in the night, and are detained in federal detainment centers and sanitariums, if not executed. The government corporation [[Characters and organizations in the Year Zero alternate reality game#Cedocore|Cedocore]] distributes the drug [[Drugs and devices in the Year Zero alternate reality game#Drugs|Parepin]] through the water supply, under the guise of it being an "immune booster" to prevent future [[bioterrorism]] attacks. However, Parepin is actually a [[psychoactive drug]], engineered to reduce aggression, affect memory retention, and instill great [[credulity]] toward authority. As a result, most Americans who drink the water become apathetic and carefree; in addition, side effects such as [[schizophrenia]]-like behavior, muscle twitches, [[anorgasmia]] are implied to have effective treatment only in urban and developed areas, discouraging people moving to rural and remote areas with untreated water. There are several underground rebel groups, mainly operating online, most notably [[Characters and organizations in the Year Zero alternate reality game#Art is Resistance|Art is Resistance]] and [[Characters and organizations in the Year Zero alternate reality game#Solutions Backwards Initiative|Solutions Backwards Initiative.]] The First Evangelical Church of Plano is a fundamentalist Protestant Christian church which is favored, and implied to be funded, by the neo-conservative government. Amidst all of this are increasing sightings of what is labelled "The Presence", which manifests as a pair of massive ghostly hands and arms extending down from the sky into the ground. Despite early attributions of The Presence to drug-induced mass hysteria, it soon becomes clear that it is a physical phenomenon capable of being recorded on video and film, although grainy and unfocused. Theories vary on the real cause of the appearances, but the prevailing opinion appears to be that the hands represent God or some other equivalent supernatural force. The sightings become more and more frequent, and those who are "touched" by the hand begin to report their experiences, mostly of a feeling of terror and clarity. On February 10, 2022, a government official named Doug is in his office tracking The Presence, while missing the birth of his daughter in Denver. He begins writing a letter to his then-unborn child, describing the state of the world and his family. Doug continually references The Presence, as more and more sightings are suddenly reported all around the planet at once. He says goodbye to his child, as the letter ends with a frantic, broken message that the Presence is above the Capitol Building and "the stars are going out like candles". It cuts off suddenly, implying reports that sightings of the phenomenon are rapidly being reported from all over the world. The sequence ends with a broken message announcing the appearance of The Presence over the United States Capitol Building. The message cuts off suddenly, implying the end of the world. Meanwhile, the Solutions Backwards Initiative - a group of students, professors, and computer experts - devise a successful means with which to send information back through time using [[quantum mechanics]] in order to prevent the dystopian future (and eventual apocalypse) they live in from ever occurring. The websites and music of the Year Zero alternate reality game are implied to be part of the information packets sent back through the wormholes, activated only moments after Doug's message. ==Media attention== The concept behind the ''Year Zero'' alternate reality game, as well as avid fan participation in the game, has caught the attention of the media numerous times; ''[[USA Today]]'' and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' have cited fan site The NIN Hotline, forum Echoing the Sound, fan club The Spiral, and [http://www.ninwiki.com NinWiki] as sources for new discoveries.{{cite web | url = http://blogs.usatoday.com/popcandy/2007/02/nins_web_of_int.html | title = NIN's web of intrigue | first = Whitney | last = Matheson | publisher = [[USA Today]] | date = 2007-02-15 | accessdate = 2007-02-15}}{{cite web | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2007/02/15/coachella-rocks-sprawl-nin-fans-marketing-teams-dream-aerosmith-pressed-for-time/ | title = NIN fans = marketing team's dream | author = Elizabeth Goodman | publisher = [[Rolling Stone]] | date = 2007-02-15 | accessdate = 2007-02-15}} ==Film and television project== In March 2007 ''[[Kerrang!]] Radio'' reported that "Reznor admitted he's already in talks about a movie version of his upcoming album a concept piece, with part two scheduled for next year." He had earlier noted ''Year Zero'' as "part of a bigger picture of a number of things I'm working on. Essentially, I wrote the soundtrack to a movie that doesn't exist." Reznor has commented that he is currently more interested in a television project than a film project. He has stated that he has a producer and has met with writers.{{cite web | url = http://www.theninhotline.net/news/index.php#1186755282 | title = I hate Contact Music | author = leviathant| publisher = The NIN Hotline | date = 2007-08-10 | accessdate = 2007-08-10}} On August 10, 2007, Reznor announced that they would soon be taking the concept to television networks in an attempt to secure a deal. "We're about to pitch it to the network, so we're a couple of weeks away from meeting all of the main people, and we'll see what happens."{{cite web | last = Adler | first = Heather | title = Nine Inch Nails Ready Apocalyptic Year Zero TV Show | publisher = [[Dose (magazine)|''Dose'']] | date = 2007-08-14 | url = http://www.dose.ca/music/story.html?id=ead25b9c-b7f0-44aa-92c7-d083b6c83e1a&k=48608 | accessdate = 2007-08-19}} Since first announcing his plans for a television series, progress has slowed, reportedly due to the [[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike|2007–2008 Writer's Guild strike]]. Despite this, Reznor has reported that the project is "still churning along".{{cite journal | publisher = ''[[Herald Sun]]'' | date = 2008-04-02 | last = Johnson | first = Neala | title = Nine Inch Nails' Trent Reznor approaches the future a free man}} Reznor clarified in November 2012 that the project was "currently in a holding state" due to himself and Rob Sheridan failing to "find the right match with a writer".{{cite web | last = Beaton | first = Connor | title = Nine Inch Nails’ Year Zero Mini-Series “In Holding State” | publisher = zConnection | date = 2012-11-13 | url = http://zcint.co.uk/article/nine-inch-nails-year-zero-miniseries-in-holding-state | accessdate = 2012-11-13}} In 2017, during an interview promoting new Nine Inch Nails EP ''[[Add Violence]]'', Reznor said that "They got so far as hiring a writer for it, but then it fell to shit because we never had the right writer. I should have just done it [myself]."{{cite web|last=Goodman|first=Lizzy|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2017/07/25/trent-reznor-nine-inch-nails-add-violence/|title=Trent Reznor's Soundtrack to the Apocalypse|publisher=The Village Voice|date=July 25, 2017|accessdate=July 27, 2017}} ==Critical reception== Many reviewers of the ''Year Zero'' album also commented on the accompanying game. [[Ann Powers]] of ''[[Los Angeles Times|The Los Angeles Times]]'' praised the album and game concept as "a total marriage of the pop and gamer aesthetics that unlocks the rusty cages of the music industry and solves some key problems facing rock music as its cultural dominance dissolves into dust."{{cite web | url = http://www.calendarlive.com/music/reviews/la-et-nails17apr17,0,817496.story?coll=cl-albumreviews | title = Nine Inch Nails creates a world from 'Year Zero' | last = Powers | first = Ann | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | accessdate = 2008-01-10 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070625205704/http://www.calendarlive.com/music/reviews/la-et-nails17apr17,0,817496.story?coll=cl-albumreviews | archivedate = 2007-06-25}} In 2008, 42 Entertainment won two [[Webby Awards]] for their work on the ''Year Zero'' game, under the categories of "Integrated Campaigns" and "Other Advertising: Branded Content".{{cite web | url = http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=98&season=12#adv_int_camp | publisher = [[Webby Awards]] | accessdate = 2008-04-09 | title = Webby Nominees – INTEGRATED CAMPAIGNS}}{{cite web | url = http://www.webbyawards.com/webbys/current.php?media_id=98&season=12#adv_ind_branded | publisher = Webby Awards | accessdate = 2008-04-09 | title = Webby Nominees – OTHER ADVERTISING: BRANDED CONTENT}} 42 Entertainment was also awarded three medals in [[One_Club#The_One_Show|The One Show]]'s entertainment award ceremony, including a gold medal in the "online gaming" category, a silver in the "music" category, and a merit award in the "online branded entertainment" category.{{cite web | url = http://www.theninhotline.net/news/#1224628072 | publisher = The NIN Hotline | accessdate = 2008-11-02 | title = 42 Entertainment wins yet again!
